page.title: 09THE CHURCH AT LEVINGTON
page.content: St. Peter's Church can be seen from the River Orwell, and might have been built as a landmark for navigation. It is thought to date from the 12th Century. The outside walls have been plastered and whitewashed, but the tower is brick. The leaning walls have been supported by brick buttresses. The church is small but most attractive. There are not many windows on the North side, because people once believed that evil spirits could enter from that side of a building. The three bells in the tower are very old. The upper stages of the tower are reached by ladders. There is some fine carving inside the church, the best being the carved oak pulpit which is early Jacobean. A new orgn has recently been installed. The church shares a Rector with neighbouring Parishes.
